HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., MARCH 7, 1924

VOL. XXVIII, No 39
ENGINEERING STUDENTS DISAPPROVE OF PROPOSED
COMBINED SOCIETY
Plan for Organization to Include Men
of All Departments Abandoned.
Combined Show to Be Given

The plan for a society to include on its rolls the members of
all the engineering departments
has finally had to be abandoned
because of lack of interest in the
suggested arrangement. The majority of the engineering students
maintain that the only function
which the proposed organization
would serve would be to provide
another ornament to be sported
on one's vest. The annual engineering show, the principal "raison d'etre" of the society as declared by its sponsors, is now being arranged by the Electric Club
in co-operation with the Mechanical and Civil Engineering Societies, and accordingly is no longer
potent as a "talking point" for the
new society. -

Hopkins baseball team. Because

authority began to wane. One bright day he decided to play golf. He
remained away from the bank, trusting that subordinates would do his
work. He enjoyed the experience and, as days progressed, he played
more and more golf, turning over all duties, important and unimportant,
to subordinates. He soon dropped in at the offices only for pay-day and
elections.
Matters, which should have been attended to by the executive, were
done in a half-hearted manner. The example set the employees was
poor and they were not inspired. Duties of importance began to be
neglected, inefficiency became the watchword. Needless to say the bank
declared no extra dividends.

"Joe" Zoller, captain of the 1922
Hopkins lacrosse team, will coach
the Red Eagle team this season.
Faulkner Hunter is managing the
team and an attractive schedule
will be arranged. Two games
apiece with Poly and City are
pending for Thursday afternoon,
and other teams will undoubtedly
be played. Any player not on the
first squad and not "on pro" is
eligible to compete in these games.

Swindell is pleased with the results
of the new system because much
material that would have probably
gone unnoticed in other years has
been discovered. "We are not
thinking of this year alone in holding these tryouts," the coach said,
"but are looking for material to replace next year the men who have
graduated from the university. For
that reason, the present system of
selecting two competitive casts is a
decided improvement over the old
method."
The tryouts have really been rehearsal, because all the candidates
are expected to profit by the coaching given to each man..Thus, while
the cast is still unselected, the play
is rapidly rounding into shape.
The scenery for the farce is all
being constructed by the production
staff of the Barnstormers. Isaac
Hamburger II is in charge of this
division of the work and under his
direction it is expected that the
stage properties will soon be completed.

HE Vice-President of a great life insurance
company who began his career as an agent
has this to say to seniors who are about to
graduate from college:

11,

"If you love work and desire to pursue an honorable,
useful and lucrative mission in life this is the business
for you to take up. Life insurance salesmanship offers
a fine field for the energies of the splendid young men
in our colleges.
"That this is true is demonstrated by those college men
who have taken up life insurance for they have shown
that the college man is fit for this kind of a job and
that the job also is fit for the college man.
"The work ofthe life insurancesalesman is distinguished
byindependence and opportunityfor directing his own.
It gives all possible opportunityfor individual initiative
and a chance to make an ample income at an age when
most fellows are struggling on a wage pittance."
That is the story of one who began at the bottom and reached
the top without the help of a college education. The advantages are with you who graduate from college. Before deciding
your career make inquiries of the "Agency Department."

NTERCOLLEGIATE
EXCHANGE

"The ways of the unrighteous are
hard," etc. The University of
Michigan will not only expell
cheaters from the university, but
will give them publicity.
* * *
A flood of applicants recently answered the call from Vassar for
three male students from Ohio
State to act as guides to Vassar
girls on a geological field trip
through the Bitter-root Mountains.
* *
'Forty-five per cent of the entire
student body at Trinity College
flunked out or went on probation
as a result of the recent Mid-years.
The ten lowest men in the Intelligence Tests either flunked out Or
went on probation.
* *
A novel means of cheating during recent examinations was carried out at West Virginia Wesleyan by a fair co-ed, who inscribed
certain useful formulas on her
ankle, underneath chiffon hose.
She was discovered by the profes sor when she was reading them off.
(This case caused a sensation in
the class room.)
* *
Nineteen of the class of 1924 at
Goucher have been elected to Phi
Beta Kappa. This constitutes 10.5
per cent of the senior class.
The students at Lehigh certainly
do go in for athletics. Recent statistics show that of 983 students
registered in the college, 951 are
connected in some way with some
sport. However, some of their
ideas of what constitutes athletics
seem a little queer. For example:
Dancing, the Band, Field Geology,
and Assistant Managers.
Randolph-Macon has succeeded
in raising $100,000 for a new gymnasium by subscriptions from the
students and alumni.

DORMITORY SHOW HELD ON
TUESDAY NIGHT
Wilson Shaffer scored a big hit
at the last Dormitory "Show" held
on Tuesday night with his new
dance numbers. Shaffer delighted
one and all with his original and
unique dance steps and was
roundly applauded for his performance. This number was the feature of the rather large and well
balanced program of the "Show."
Several of the well known songs
of the school were sung—Albert
Corby gave a fine violin solo, Fitzgerald entertained with two numbers on the ukelele, a number of
men gave a Round Table of new
and amusing jokes and the pro.
-ram wos closed with the son."Come Stand Together."
The House Committee plans to
run these shows or entertainments
about twice a month as the men
of the Dormitory seem to take a
great deal of interest in them.
There is an astonishing amount of
talent in the Dormitory and these
little programs will bring out
many a man with ability for the
Musical and Dramatic Clubs. The
next "Show" will be run off on
March 25. Work has already been
started on the program. One new
addition will be the "Furious
Five," a quintet Of unrivaled songsters.

WANTED—AN AXE
To the Editor of the
NEWS-LETTER:
As lacrosse and baseball seasons
approach may I be permitted to call
attention to that infernal nuisance
that has ruined many a contest for
me and for other spectators, that
tree which stands in front of the
rooting section at Homewood Field.
For two years the darned thing has
obstructed the vision of the rooters
at crucial moments of many games.
More curses have been heaped upon its (theoretical) head than upon
the course in Physics I.
It cannot be so useful in its mission of beautifying the grounds, or
of holding up an arc light as to
warrant its retention to obstruct the
gaze of spectators.
This beastly, ugly specimen of
denuded fir tree cannot serve any
other purpose than to irritate. Then
there can be no reason for not having it removed. May the Athletic
Office take a hint. I doubt if it will.
H. R. T.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., MARCH 7, 1924

VOL. XXVIII, No 39
ENGINEERING STUDENTS DISAPPROVE OF PROPOSED
COMBINED SOCIETY
Plan for Organization to Include Men
of All Departments Abandoned.
Combined Show to Be Given

The plan for a society to include on its rolls the members of
all the engineering departments
has finally had to be abandoned
because of lack of interest in the
suggested arrangement. The majority of the engineering students
maintain that the only function
which the proposed organization
would serve would be to provide
another ornament to be sported
on one's vest. The annual engineering show, the principal "raison d'etre" of the society as declared by its sponsors, is now being arranged by the Electric Club
in co-operation with the Mechanical and Civil Engineering Societies, and accordingly is no longer
potent as a "talking point" for the
new society. -

girls on a geological field trip
through the Bitter-root Mountains.

'Forty-five per cent of the entire
student body at Trinity College
flunked out or went on probation
as a result of the recent Mid-years.
The ten lowest men in the Intelligence Tests either flunked out Or
went on probation.
* *
A novel means of cheating during recent examinations was carried out at West Virginia Wesleyan by a fair co-ed, who inscribed
certain useful formulas on her
ankle, underneath chiffon hose.
She was discovered by the profes sor when she was reading them off.
(This case caused a sensation in
the class room.)

Nineteen of the class of 1924 at
Goucher have been elected to Phi
Beta Kappa. This constitutes 10.5
per cent of the senior class.
The students at Lehigh certainly
do go in for athletics. Recent statistics show that of 983 students
registered in the college, 951 are
connected in some way with some
sport. However, some of their
ideas of what constitutes athletics
seem a little queer. For example:
Dancing, the Band, Field Geology,
and Assistant Managers.

DORMITORY SHOW HELD ON
TUESDAY NIGHT
Wilson Shaffer scored a big hit
at the last Dormitory "Show" held
on Tuesday night with his new
dance numbers. Shaffer delighted
one and all with his original and
unique dance steps and was
roundly applauded for his performance. This number was the feature of the rather large and well
balanced program of the "Show."
Several of the well known songs
of the school were sung—Albert
Corby gave a fine violin solo, Fitzgerald entertained with two numbers on the ukelele, a number of
men gave a Round Table of new
and amusing jokes and the pro.
-ram wos closed with the son."Come Stand Together."
The House Committee plans to
run these shows or entertainments
about twice a month as the men
of the Dormitory seem to take a
great deal of interest in them.
There is an astonishing amount of
talent in the Dormitory and these
little programs will bring out
many a man with ability for the
Musical and Dramatic Clubs. The
next "Show" will be run off on
March 25. Work has already been
started on the program. One new
addition will be the "Furious
Five," a quintet Of unrivaled songsters.

WANTED—AN AXE
To the Editor of the
NEWS-LETTER:
As lacrosse and baseball seasons
approach may I be permitted to call
attention to that infernal nuisance
that has ruined many a contest for
me and for other spectators, that
tree which stands in front of the
rooting section at Homewood Field.
For two years the darned thing has
obstructed the vision of the rooters
at crucial moments of many games.
More curses have been heaped upon its (theoretical) head than upon
the course in Physics I.
It cannot be so useful in its mission of beautifying the grounds, or
of holding up an arc light as to
warrant its retention to obstruct the
gaze of spectators.
This beastly, ugly specimen of
denuded fir tree cannot serve any
other purpose than to irritate. Then
there can be no reason for not having it removed. May the Athletic
Office take a hint. I doubt if it will.
H. R. T.
